Inflation is not confirmed, of course, but is supported by the discovery a 
while ago of gravitational waves in the CMB. If Inflation did occur, this 
is what we would have expected to see, and we did.
Information cannot travel faster than light through space. A black hole 
only stops light beyond its event horizon, and at that point time stops, 
you wouldn't be falling anywhere.
Also, light we see from the most distant galaxies is extremely red-shifted, 
which is just one of many pieces of evidence that shows that space is 
expanding.
The expansion of space is a pretty well supported theory, it's hard to 
debunk.
And since no one has any idea what can cause a piece of space-time fabric 
to expand for so long, they just call it dark energy. And it's got to be 
something new to us.

comments.text:
He is talking about the "standard model," string theory, and dark matter. 
You need a bit of background to understand what he is talking about.
        The *standard model* is like the periodic table of elements, except 
instead of elements of atoms, each square in the table are sub-atomic 
particles like photons, electrons, quarks, neutrinos the stuff that make up 
atoms and energy -- and also their more exotic cousins that we never seen 
in our day-to-day lives. The most elusive of these particles was the "Higgs 
Boson" which is the particle that gravity is made of. It was recently 
proved to exist at the LHC particle physic laboratory run by the CERN group.
        *String theory* is the theory that all of these particles are made 
of tiny vibrating strings, like in a piano, and the "note" is what decides 
what the particle is. So for example if a string's vibration is that of a 
"C" note, it becomes an electron, and it if it's vibration is that of an 
"A" note, it is a quark.
        *Dark matter* is matter that is completely mysterious to us. The 
only reason we know it exists is because we are seeing "holes" in the 
universe (I don't mean black holes, dark matter is even more mysterious 
than that). For example galaxies that ought to be collapsing due to gravity 
but for some reason are expanding like there is an invisible force tearing 
them apart slowly. We can see the "holes" but don't know how they got 
there. We think the cause may be some unseen form of matter and energy that 
we have called "dark matter" because we cannot see it directly.
        What Michio Kaku is saying here is that "dark matter" is very 
likely made of those other kinds of particles of "higher octaves" of 
vibrating strings, which are particles in the standard model that are 
completely different from the kind of stuff we see in ordinary matter and 
energy on Earth.
        I think you will like these short videos that explain what I am 
talking about better:

CERN: The Standard Model Of Particle Physics

String Ducky

Patricia Burchat: Shedding light on dark matter

http://xkcd.com/171/

comments.text:
i'm not sure i understand your question, so i'll probably say a bunch of 
things you already know and not actually say anything new, but here is some 
info i think it's precious to share (read everything just in case i got 
it): according to the big bang model ( everything i'm going to say is 
according to the big bang model, or so i think ) the galaxies further away 
are not closer to the big bang ( in space ), because the big bang didn't 
have a position. you are just as close to the big bang as the most distant 
star known to man. that's because the initial singularity that 'went bang' 
is not the origin of the universe, it is the universe itself. i'll take 
Michio's example: imagine a balloon that at it's uninflated state is a 
point. now start to inflate it : the point becomes a little sphere and it 
keeps expanding. in this scenario, if you place some marks on the balloon 
(in this analogy the points on the surface are the galaxies and the center 
of the baloon is the big bang) you will notice two things: 1-every point on 
the surface has the same distance from the centre, and 2-if you place 
multiple points, say, on the equator, at regular intervals, as the balloon 
expands those points will still be on regular intervals. if you draw an 
image on the balloon, that image will simply get bigger, without deforming. 
that's because the balloon is expanding isomorphically ( or at least i 
think that's the word ), it basically keeps it's shape and the ratios 
between distances remain the same. so basically don't confuse the 
galaxy-galaxy distance with the galaxy-big bang site distance. in the 
balloon analogy the universe is a 2D surface, but the expanding singularity 
is a 3D sphere, and in reality the universe is a 3D space that is expanding 
in the fourth dimension like Michio said. of course we can't see that, a 
fourth dimensional event cannot be perceived by a three-dimensional entity 
in it's entirety, only it's shadow. ok that was confusing, but basically 
the big bang is all around us, in a sense it is us. speaking about the 
distance of a point from the big bang site is meaningless, if you are 
speaking in three-dimensional terms.
now back to the balloon analogy: if it is true that the universe is 
expanding regularly in all directions, how come, as you said ( and again 
you may already know this, and it's not like i am implying that i am right, 
if you think i am wrong, tell me ) that the galaxies that are futher away 
are 'escaping' us faster ? shouldn't they go at the same speed as every 
other galaxy if the universe is expanding isomorphically ? the answer is 
no. to understand why, let's take a segment, on that segment mark the end 
point A, the end point B and the middle point M. now if you fix A into 
position and move B twice as far as before from A, you will get a segment 
that is twice as long. and of course M has moved as well to the middle of 
the new segment, but notice that, starting from A, B has moved more than M. 
twice as much the distance in fact. in the same amount of time, B, that is 
twice as far from A as M is, has covered twice as much distance as M has. 
so in this sense B was twice as fast as M. in fact not only galaxies that 
are further away go faster, but galaxies twice as far away from us as other 
galaxies move away at twice the speed.
so when astrophisicists say that ''the universe is accelerating'' 
as prosperomage said in response to you, they don't mean that galaxies 
further away move away faster, because that is just the consequence of the 
geometry of an expanding universe. they mean that galaxies are moving away 
even faster than they should and the speed keeps increasing for reasons 
unknown.
now, how do we notice that galaxies are going away from us and the ones 
twice as far away from us as others are going twice as fast as them (let's 
assume, for semplicity's sake, that the universe is not accelerating)? you 
already know this: redshift. galaxies that are twice as far away from us as 
other galaxies are also twice as redshifted ( their light is twice as 
redshifted, i should say ). but what about the galaxies that are so far 
away that their light is reaching us right now, showing us how they looked 
like 13 billion years ago? well that light is subjected to the same rules 
about redshift as any other light, so i don't think there would be any 
difference.
oh, maybe now i got it: i think that maybe your question was something like 
''that light comes from almoust the beginning of the universe, so shouldn't 
it have some special property ?'' maybe you are asking ''if when we look at 
the far space we look at how things were, and the further we look the older 
things are, then if the universe is accelerating in his expansion shouldn't 
we actually see an ever-slowing expansion as we look further and further 
away in space and in the past?'' it's almoust like a paradox: if the 
universe is accelerating, then galaxies are going away faster and faster, 
but the further away we look the more into the past we look, when things 
were not as fast, therefore the further away we look the slower and slower 
things should go. mmmm.....(ten minutes go by)....ok, let's see: if a 
photon A leaves one of this first stars and travels through an expanding 
universe, it will get redshifted in the process and  that is what we 
actually measure. the more time it takes for the photon to reach us, the 
more is subjetced to the expansion of the space-time and the more it gets 
redshifted. but if a photon B from a closer/later star begins its voyage 
towards us and it gets redshifted, B will start with a more powerful 
redshift that A, so A has 'wasted a bunch of time' with a redshift weaker 
than B. B will get more redshift per unit of time than A has by the time it 
reacheh earth. so if A was twice as far away as B was from us by the time 
they begun their journey, if the redshifting was stable A would be twice as 
redshifted as B is, but since redshifting is increasing, A should be less 
than twice as redshifted as B is. but measurments say it is more, so what 
is going on here ? my answer is: maybe astronomers already considered the 
fact that two photons that reach us at the same time but from two stars at 
different distances and extrapolated the data, but i don't know. either 
there is something basic i am missing or i need to look up some serious 
literature. 
wow, all this and i probably still didn't answer your question, that must 
be annoying huh....well, if i learn something new, i'll tell you, deal?

comments.text:
+buksuke
An electron cloud is technically infinitely large, but of course it's more 
conveniently defined out to some sigma cutoff, which results in some shape 
for the cloud in 3d space.
The electron cloud "shape" I hinted at above is a result of the solution of 
the wave equation for the electron, then truncated out to that probability 
tolerance. If you haven't seen orbital shapes before, they're pretty neat.  
http://chemwiki.ucdavis.edu/Physical_Chemistry/Quantum_Mechanics/Atomic_Theory/Electrons_in_Atoms/Electronic_Orbitals
Of course, Even if you ignore the electron's probability field, the "empty 
space" that's left over is still subject to Heisenberg's Uncertainty 
Principle, which results in the space being "filled" with virtual particles 
(this roiling phenomenon at the small scale is called quantum foam).

comments.author: buksuke

comments.text:
There's no "empty space" inside an atom. Now, when you really think about 
it, "empty space" becomes kind of a tricky concept to define, and it 
depends on the scale at which you look at the space. For example, there's a 
story about a philosophy (?) professor doing a demonstration in class, 
where he fills a cup with marbles, asks "Is there empty space in this cup?" 
(and the students answer "no"), then pours sand into the cup, asks "Is 
there empty space in this cup?" ("no"), then pours water in and so on. The 
point is that "empty space" is not a specific technical term. A particular 
region of space could be considered empty or full or something in between, 
depending on which definition you're using; and definitions differ.
With atoms, what's really going on is that the space outside the nucleus is 
filled with the quantum fields that represent an electron. (It's slightly 
tautological to say that because a field fills space by definition, but 
let's not worry about that.) The electron itself is very very small, 
essentially pointlike, so it doesn't really take up any space on its own, 
and thus you might argue that all the volume of the atom (outside the 
nucleus), minus the size of one electron, is empty. But on the other hand, 
there's some probability of the electron being anywhere within the atom, so 
by another definition, it's not really accurate to say that that space is 
empty if there's some chance an electron could show up in it. In 
particular, the space within an atom is not quite the same as what 
physicists consider a vacuum, because there's a significant probability 
that you'll find an electron in the atom whereas the probability is much 
less in a vacuum.
So the "empty space" is really just the electron cloud. We can never be 
sure of where the electron will be, so we broadly define it as orbitals 
within that area of what is traditionally thought of as "empty space".

comments.text:
+bescuit "How does anything exist if it adds up to zero"You can have a net 
worth of zero but still have assets. The assets are just offset by debts. 
Debt in this case is the negative energy driving the expansion of the 
universe. It provides energy, which per Einstein's famous equation is just 
matter in a different form.

captions.text:
We have found the Higgs boson.  So then the
next question is what's next?  Well the Large

Hadron Collider, this machine that is 27 miles
in circumference, costing 10 billion dollars

is big enough to create the next generation
of particles.  So the Higgs boson in some

sense is the last hurrah for the old physics,
the old physics of what is called the standard

model, which gives us quarks and electrons. 
The new theory is going to take us into dark

matter.  Now we know dark matter exists. 
Dark matter is invisible, so if I held it

in my hand you wouldn't see it.  In fact,
it would go right through my fingers, go right

through the rock underneath my feet and go
all the way to China.  It would reverse direction

and come back from China all the way here
to New York City and go back and forth.

So dark matter has gravitational attraction,
but it is invisible and we are clueless as

to what dark matter really is.  The leading
candidate for dark matter today is called

the sparticle.  The sparticle is the next
octave of the string.  Now look around you.

Everything around you, we think, is nothing
but the lowest vibration of a vibrating string,

the lowest octave in some sense, but a string
of course has higher octaves, higher notes.

We think that dark matter could in fact be
nothing but a higher vibration of the string.

So we think that 23% of the universe, which
is the dark matter's contribution to the universe,

comes from a higher octave of the string. 
Now the standard model which we have ample

verification of only represents four percent
of the universe.  So the universe of atoms,

protons, neutrons, neutrinos - that universe
only represents four percent of what there

is.  23% is dark matter, which we think is
the next vibration up of the string and then

73% of the universe is dark energy. 
Dark energy is the energy of nothing.  It's

the energy of the vacuum.  Between two objects
in outer space there is nothing, nothing except

dark energy, dark energy, which is pushing
the galaxies apart.  So when people say if

the universe is expanding they say two things,
what's pushing the galaxies apart and what

is the universe expanding into.  Well what's
pushing the galaxies apart is dark energy,

the energy of nothing.  Even vacuum has energy
pushing the galaxies apart.  And then what

is the universe expanding into?  Well if
the universe is a sphere of some sort and

we live on the skin of the sphere and the
sphere is expanding what is the sphere expanding

into?  Well obviously a bubble, a balloon
expands into the third dimension even though

the people living on the balloon are two dimensional.
So when our universe expands what does it

expand into?  Hyperspace, a dimension beyond
what you can see and touch.  In fact, string

theory predicts that there are 11 dimensions
of hyperspace, so we're nothing but a soap

bubble floating in a bubble bath of soap bubbles
and so in some sense the multiverse can be

likened to a bubble bath.  Our universe is
nothing but one bubble, but there are other

bubbles.  When two bubbles collide that could
merge into a bigger bubble, which could be

the big bang.  In fact, that is what probably
the big bang is or perhaps a bubble fissioned

in half and split off into two bubbles. 
That could be the big bang.  Or perhaps the

universe popped into existence out of nothing. 
That is also a possibility.

And so the universe could essentially be nothingness,
which was unstable and created a soap bubble

Now you may say to yourself well that can't
be right because that violates the conservation

of matter and energy.  How can you create
a universe from nothing?  Well if you calculate

the total matter of the universe it is positive. 
If you calculate the total energy of the universe

it is negative because of gravity.  Gravity
has negative energy.  When you add the two

together what do you get?  Zero, so it takes
no energy to create a universe.  Universes

are for free.  A universe is a free lunch. 
And then you may say to yourself well that

can't be right because positive and negative
charges don't cancel out, therefore, how can

the universe be made out of nothing. Well
if you calculate the total amount of positive

charge in the universe and calculate the total
amount of negative charge in the universe

and you add it up what do you get?  Zero,
the universe has zero charge.  Well what

about spin?  Galaxies spin, right?  But
they spin in all directions.  If you add

up all the spins of the galaxies what do you
get?  Zero, so in other words, the universe

has zero spin, zero charge and zero matter
energy content.  In other words, the universe
is for free.

title: Michio Kaku: Space Bubble Baths  and the Free Universe
